tweets.text: 1. All subcultures have dark sides. Seeing the darkness in yours is an advanced Jungian kind of thing, which won't make you many friends. https://t.co/vg6AJE1Gli
2. The dark sides of a subculture are often directly tied to their bright sides: e.g. outmoded thinking for SCA, techno-fetish for software.
3. Hearing directly about the dark sides of a subculture from outsiders is often a warning sign that shit's gone badly sideways.
4. Subcultures are often where rejects go. Most of the time this is good, but some people were rejected for good reason.
5. Because of rejection sensitivity, many subcultures (especially the sexual ones, but not exclusively) have an issue with missing-stair abusers.
6. Many subcultures have dumb beef with subcultures a door or two away: punks vs. goths, SCA vs. LARP. It's all very religious.
7. The chief value proposition of a subculture seems to be the value proposition itself: "we value different things than mainstream culture".
8. Because of this, subcultures often have weird value hierarchies that are 90%+ founder effects and survivor bias.
9. Subcultures can be oddly stacked like matryoshka dolls, often driven by the "group chat minus that one person" effect.
10. It's good odds that "that one person" is either a popular abuser, or someone who called out a popular abuser.
11. Popular abusers love to make counter-claims, sometimes even before their accuser can, making it difficult to tell which is "right".
12. Small pool subcultures often make for tin-pot-tyrants, because exercising power over ten is easier than thousands.
13. Many subcultures demand expensive signaling that reduces ability to function in normal culture.
14. Instead of providing protection from the slings of mainstream culture (as hoped), this often makes members more vulnerable.
15. That extra vulnerability often drives low status members of the deeper into the arms of the tin-pots and missing-stairs.
16. Subcultures are, in fact, the darker side of over-culture: the rejection of the proposition that one-size-fits-all.
17. This means almost any subculture worth its salt is also a hindrance to public life in over-culture.
18. That in turn means that subculture membership is often secret, and a source of potential leverage against members.
19. This goes double when the subculture actively violates over-culture norms: e.g. sexual subcultures.
20. Outing -- the practice of revealing the subculture membership of another -- is therefore almost universally reviled.
21. Many early adopters of a subculture dislike late adopters precisely because they're watering down the transgressive parts.
22. Despite this, broad adoption of a subculture is often a win for its values, which (in diluted form) gain acceptability.
23. Due to this, every subculture has an internal tension between those wanting to share and those wanting purity.
24. Few subcultures look too deeply at their origin myths, because 90%+ were really "the founders were comfortable and bored".
25. Therefore, the culture heroes they revere are often early adopters instead, who could go whole hog with less irony of purpose.
26. Exceptions to this come when a subculture is actually just a cult, possibly due to hollowing out from a tin-pot.
27. In cults, any early adopter culture heroes are kept close by cynical leadership, because they're risky if uncontrolled.
28. Specifically, the risk is that the culture hero recognizes the cynicism at the center, and forms a new subculture via "group chat minus one".
29. In healthier cultures, the culture heroes are kept at arms distance by the founders, because they're too serious about it.
30. The tighter the subculture, the more insular and unhealthy it is likely to be.
31. The looser the subculture, the more of an vague excuse for sex, drugs, and scene appropriate music it's likely to be.
32. There's a sweet spot in the middle, where neither hedonism nor priesthood holds a ton of sway.
33. That sweet spot is where the most valuable work of subcultures actually gets done. It also dissolves as quickly as an actual sweet.
(Okay, that's enough for today, I think. More tomorrow, or as I get more actual insight.)
34. Subcultures form around anything, but there are broad categories. Ethnicity, religion, politics, and class are traditional ones.
35. Starting with the Age of Sail and accelerating heavily in the Industrial Age, business subculture acts traditional but is not.
36. Interest-based subcultures are more modern, depending on increased communication range. Music-fashion ones are the best known.
37. You can be a member of many subcultures, but its difficult to be a member of two of the same base category: e.g. you can be a working-class Christian, but not a Muslim Christian (easily).
38. If two subcultures have easy cross-over, they're probably built around non-competing values: e.g. SCA (history nerd) v. Renn Faire (acting nerd).
39. If two subcultures have no easy cross-over, they're either built around opposed values -- conservative v. liberal -- or different claims to the same value -- e.g. Catholic v. Protestant.
40. Opposed values subcultures will never really like each other, but can reach a dente. Opposing claims can almost never reconcile, save temporarily in the presence of a superior outside force.

41. Interest-based cultures tend to be non-competing, but this is not complete, since they all compete for attention. Music-fashion was a notable exception in my youth, but this appears to have decreased.

42. On the deep end of the competing for attention pool lives the infamous holy wars of open source nerds -- emacs v. vim, Linux v. BSD, et. al. ad nauseum -- because having the attention can make or break a project.
43. All of which is to say that the fights inside and across subcultures can look super-petty from the outside, but they're often about real stakes, expressed in values you just don't share.
44. With all that as prelude, some subcultures I have known and loved^Wloathed^Wparticipated in. If I insult you, I beg you remember that I'm poking at myself here, too.

45. Quakers: I was raised one. Not the Mennonite-like Shakers, just very left-wing Christians. Values: egalitarian, peaceful. Failings: consensus decision making vulnerable to squeaky wheels, generally toothless.
46. Tabletop RPGs: my home territory. Values: self-entertainment, small group dynamics. Failings: describing my 17th level paladin to strangers, socializing (outside immediate friends).

47. SCA: another long-time group of mine. Heavy overlap with other groups. Many internal subcultures, down to the Pennsic camp size. Values: history, romantic chivalry. Failings: realistic chivalry & other antiquated mindsets.

48. USENET nerd: probably my oldest "adult" grouping, though I was still in HS. Defunct, but wide effects downstream. Values: individualism, self-determination. Failings: trolls, blowhards, free-for-all.

49. Subgenius: my religion, if we're being technical, found via USENET. Values: self-determination, rejection of overculture rejection. Failings: incoherence, rejection sensitivity, overculture rejection.

50. Goth: I was "not a goth" in my youth: I listened to industrial music, wore black, smoked cloves, but I wasn't no joiner. Values: individualism, rejection of overculture religion. Failings: hedonism, lack of innovation.
51. Raves: had a larger than you might expect overlap with goth, maybe due to a mutual love for X. Values: Peace Love Unity Respect. Failings: hedonism, broken stairs, empty values.
52. LGBT: gender and sexuality aren't cultural choices, but the expression of them definitely are. Values: self-acceptance, anti-bigotry. Failings: broken stairs, lots of left-leaning partisanship.

53. Kink: about a million tiny subcultures, overlapping and bound together (ha) by being sexual and unacceptable to overculture. Values: kink-acceptance, negotiation. Failings: broken stairs, consent is tricky.

54. (I don't fit in well in the sexual subcultures, even those I'm part of, and even to my own poor standards of "fit in". Part of this is due to the failings, part of it no doubt due to my own issues.)

55. Burners: an odd offshoot of San Francisco Bay startup culture (see below). Probably actually 5-8 distinct subcultures in a trenchcoat. Values: art, self-reliance, self-expression, drugs. Failings: cargo culting, overculture rejection, art uber alles, drugs.

56. LARP: an odd mix of tabletop RPGs and HS drama club. Has subsubcultures per game chapter, some with crossover, some without. Values: dramatic enactment, character immersion. Failings: drama (OMG the drama), immersion-induced issues (aka bleed), tin-pot dictators.
57. Open source software: another of my home tribes; I owe my career to it. Values: rough consensus and running code, "nobody knows you're a dog". Failings: soft skills, UI design.

58. Enterprise software: the people who will own the world in 100 years. Values: meritocracy, planning, accounting. Failings: overplanning, blame game, @vgr's Gervais Principle https://t.co/gGFHydTpX8.

@vgr 59. VC and startups: the people carving up the world for enterprise consumption. Values: move fast and break stuff, shoot for the moon. Failings: burning money, employee exploitation, lots of backdoor hiring for enterprise (via talent acquisitions).

@vgr 60. Memelords: slap some words on a picture (or a video, if you fancy) for self-expression. Values: originality, virality, riffing on themes. Failings: write-only discourse, fast-moving context, nihilism.

@vgr 61. Working class: the lower ~75% of the world that collectively own almost jack shit. Values: family, friends, entertainment. Failings: largely Loser (per @vgr) and can no longer easily ignore it.

@vgr 62. The following I've only been near, not participated deeply in, so I really shouldn't be talking shit. But we're on a roll, and frankly if you're 60+ posts in, you should probably know what you're in for by now.

@vgr 63. Anon: grown in 4chan as an object lesson in complete lack of accountability. Values: anonymity, absurdity, trolling. Failings: right-wing partisanship, weaponized autism (arguably also a value).
@vgr 64. Renn Faire: looks a shitload like the SCA, but it's drama club, not D&D nerds. Values: performance. Failings: drama (seems a common failing of actor cultures).
@vgr 65. Blockchain: one of the many reactions to the ultra-rich, from tech nerds who either want to beat them or join them via a backdoor. Values: decentralization. Failings: infighting, scams.

@vgr 66. Punk: I'd be a punk if it weren't for the music or the clothing. Values: practical anarchy, four chords and the truth. Failings: more dissonant than experimental jazz, hard to dance to, not dying but fading away.
@vgr 67. Maker: tech nerd culture, heavy overlap with Burner, startups, upper-class. Values: DIY, experimentation. Failings: accidentally classist due to costs, lots of squandered potential.
@vgr 68. Upper-class: the management and elite professional class. Values: productivity, The Good Life. Failings: largely Clueless, with climbing Sociopaths.
@vgr 69. Political government: the electable portion of government. More at dente across party lines than they want to admit to anyone but each other. Values: leadership. Failings: corruption.
@vgr 70. Civil government: the hired / appointed portion of government. Values: job security, by-the-book. Failings: bureaucracy, inflexible process.

@vgr 71. Ultra-rich: I have no idea what this is like in practice, and neither do you, because they own most of the lawyers, PR firms, and media. Values: posterity, control. Failings: probably Sociopaths, ::vague gestures at everything::
@vgr 72. Finally, some things which look like subcultures but which probably aren't:

@vgr 73. Middle-class: this is the place where aspiring upper-class and top-tier working class would mix. It pretty much only exists in sitcoms now. (There are other places where they mix, but they're all subcultural these days.)

@vgr 74. Social media platforms: Twitter is host to many subcultures, but no generalization emerges easily. Smaller platforms may have more definite culture, but in practice its broader cultures expressing (or growing) there.

@vgr 75. Political parties: in practice only fringe parties are actually coherent subcultures. The major parties are odd bedfellows of mostly-not-opposed political subcultures, which is more visible in today's fractious clime.

@vgr 76. Well, it looks like I'm likely to fall a little short of the full 100, but I think I've covered everything I wanted to. I'll put in some closing thoughts, and then reserve the remainder for future shit-talking purposes.

@vgr 77. The darkest side of subcultures is this: they're far more our real culture than (largely national) overcultures are. Everyone pretends to be "normal", but that picture of normal is one only achieved by abjectly failing as a human being.

@vgr 78. Instead, much of what's normal in overculture is dictated to us by a variety of elite subcultures, most of them traditional but more and more coming from businesses in the 20th and 21st centuries.

@vgr 79. None of the elites dictating "normal" participate in it to any serious degree. It is a prescription to make the vast majority of other subcultures legible to the elites, not for mutual comprehension.

@vgr 80. I realized this relatively early, and started surfing between subcultures soon after I left my parent's house. Much of what I know is from direct observational experience, and should be taken with those grains of salt.

@vgr 81. My reasoning for this was, and remains, very simple: Yeats is right. The center cannot hold. Overculture will continue for years to come, but it's lost a lot of its power, and will continue to lose more.

@vgr 82. Current overcultures depend on power outpacing communication: the ability to censor competing value systems. This assumption was very true in the 20th century, and is utterly broken in the 21st.
@vgr 83. If we do make a global culture post the death of overculture, it will not be from its corpse. Instead, that culture will have to be forged from what remains: the subcultures.

@vgr 84. So if I've painted a bleak picture of them, it is in the hope that as we start thinking of how we'll build that culture, we don't spend too much energy on reverence for the small part of it that we come from.

@vgr 85. We're all fucking weirdos, we can't even fully agree about trivial things like text editors, we all struggle with insularity and banality, and ignoring our own failings while sneering at others' is playing a mug's game set up by a dying overculture.

(Fin.)
